justification: "Numerous studies have proposed that the late posterior positivity (or the LPP) is an electrophysiological marker of recollection-based recognition".

The CPP "is a posterior positive deflection… Its amplitude scales with the strength of the perceptual signal accumulated to a decision threshold," identifying it as a neural read-out of evidence accumulation.

During the recognition task, "participants reported… their decision confidence using 6-point likert scale ('Definitely old,' 'Probably old,' 'Maybe old,' 'Maybe new,' 'Probably new,' 'Definitely new')."
